item.description:
"The People v. Leo Frank" tells the story not just of what people even then believed to be an anti-Semitic kangaroo court railroading a man because of his religion, not because of the facts, but of life for Jews in the American South almost 100 years ago.  In 1913, 13-year-old Mary Phagan was found dead in the basement of the National Pencil Company in Atlanta. The courtroom drama, death sentence and eventual lynching of Jewish plant supervisor Leo Frank remains one of the most complex episodes in American, Southern and Jewish history.

Connecticut Premiere
THE PEOPLE V LEO FRANK

USA, 2009, 86 minutes, English
Director: Ben Loeterman

View trailer

 

Contains mature content and graphic images; Parental guidance suggested.

Reel Talk Following Film:

Invited Guest Speaker: Ben Loeterman, Director, The People V Leo Frank

Ben Loeterman writes, directs and produces historical and public affairs documentaries, primarily for public television. He has won national Emmy awards and two DuPont-Columbia journalism awards.

 

This film and the discussion are part of the annual Hartford Jewish Film Festival.  A number of the films will be posted, if you're interested in the full schedule look here:  http://www.hjff.org/schedule.shtml
